Description:en: Quantifies the degree of eye deviation
Assesses the ability of the eyes to converge (move inward) when focusing on a near object
Measures the eye's ability to focus on a near object
Assesses the full range of eye movements in all directions
Evaluates the reaction of the pupils to light and accommodation
Anisocoria refers to a condition where the pupils of the eyes are of unequal size
Heterochromia is a condition where the irises of the two eyes are of different colors
The direct light reflex refers to the constriction of the pupil when light is shone directly into the eye
The indirect light reflex, or consensual light reflex, occurs when shining a light into one eye causes constriction of the pupil in the opposite eye
The swinging flashlight test is used to detect a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), which indicates asymmetry in the afferent pathways of the optic nerve
The accommodation reflex (or near reflex) involves the pupils constricting, the lenses thickening, and the eyes converging when focusing on a near object
Assesses depth perception and binocular vision
Assesses binocular vision and detect suppression or abnormal retinal correspondence
Detects macular or central visual field defects
Assesses the ability to perceive colors accurately
Examines the angle of the anterior chamber of the eye
Measures the forward protrusion of the eye
Assesses the quality and quantity of the tear film
Assesses the position of the upper eyelid
The test assesses pupils reaction to light
The position and symmetry of the upper eyelid crease to determine function of levator muscle
MRD measures the distance between the corneal light reflex and the margin of the upper eyelid
This is the distance between the upper and lower eyelids when the eyes are open
This test measures the function of the levator muscle by determining the amount of upper eyelid movement from downgaze to upgaze
This evaluation checks the movement of the eyes in all directions

This test involves instilling phenylephrine drops into the eye to temporarily elevate the eyelid. It helps in diagnosing the type of ptosis and predicting the surgical outcome by assessing the response of the Müller’s muscle, which can contribute to eyelid elevation
Answers: No Rise in MRD;Rise in MRD 1.5mm
